dialogue.statement: Hi there! How are you feeling today? What's been on your mind lately?
Hey, I’ve been feeling pretty overwhelmed honestly. Aleks has been dominating my time and it's stressing me out because I'm falling behind in my other classes.

statement.reasoning: The client's story includes their struggle with managing time due to Aleks, leading to stress and burnout. They have shared detailed context and emotions related to this, indicating rapport. The goals of understanding the client's challenges and feelings have been met.

dialogue.statement: Balancing everything can really be tough. How do you think things might be different if you found a way to manage your time better between Aleks and your other classes?

client(guiding): I think if I could manage my time better, I wouldn't be so swamped and I'd have a clearer head. It would be nice to not feel so rushed and to actually have some time for myself without always worrying about deadlines.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a desire for change and the benefits it would bring. However, specific change goals or next steps have not been clearly defined. Confidence in the ability to manage time better hasn't been assessed, and there's still a need to address ambivalence about handling multiple responsibilities.

dialogue.statement: Having that clear headspace seems important to you. What do you think it would mean for your overall well-being to have that balance and a bit more time for yourself?
client(guiding): I think it would make a huge difference. I'd probably feel less anxious and more in control. Having time for myself would help me recharge and maybe even enjoy my other classes more.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed clear Change Talk with intentions to manage time better and improve well-being. A specific goal of balanced time management has been identified, and the client envisions positive outcomes from this change. Confidence appears to be relatively high, and ambivalence has decreased. These factors suggest readiness to move to the Choosing phase to develop an action plan.

dialogue.statement: Looking at ways to prioritize your time better could really support that sense of control and enjoyment you're seeking. What are some steps you might consider taking to create that balance between your classes and personal time?

client(choosing): I guess I could try setting stricter boundaries for when I work on Aleks and make sure I stick to them. Maybe creating a detailed schedule for all my classes and sticking to it could help, or even finding small breaks to relax could make a difference.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a clear goal of better time management to alleviate stress and improve well-being. They have also outlined a concrete action plan to set boundaries and create a schedule. Barriers like needing to maintain work hours are acknowledged, and there is a commitment to finding a balance. They have shown confidence in their ability to manage time better, indicating readiness to move beyond Choosing.

dialogue.statement:
Setting boundaries and creating a detailed schedule sounds like a solid plan to achieve that balance. It’s great that you’re considering small breaks too, as they can really help recharge your energy. Taking these steps could lead to feeling more in control and less anxious. You've identified some practical strategies that align well with what you want for yourself. Remember, small changes can often make a big impact over time.

As you move forward, consider starting with one or two changes and gradually building from there. It’s important to be kind to yourself as you adjust to this new routine. If you ever need to revisit these strategies or explore new ones, I’ll be here to support you. You’re taking positive steps forward, and I’m confident that with these adjustments, you’ll find the balance you’re looking for.
Thanks, I’ll definitely start with small changes and see how it goes. It’s reassuring to know I can come back for more guidance if needed.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified time management strategies and a plan to implement them, which aligns with their goals. They expressed readiness to start making changes and acknowledged the option to seek further support if needed.

concern:
title: Anyone using Aleks math? What are your thoughts on it? (Story)
The concept makes sense, but it is repetitive. All three of my math professors have used aleks due to blended classes. So students Aleks are different from each other. This professor was more annoying due to her giving us so much damn work, I was doing more math than any of my other class work for other classes. My professor once thought it was a good idea to give us 74 topics once, but in a span of two weeks so there was sometime to it. I lost my mind and got up to 53. I ended up passing the class. 

The second one, I did fine in the first half and the topics were a lot less compared to the first class, but I started to be in a deep burnout state and even getting COVID that I gave up and failed the class due to constantly completing Aleks and just saying fuck all to any topics and assignments.

Now my third professor and I’m making up the class. I’ve somewhat came up with a better system to complete them: on average, it’s 24 topics due in a span of 3-4 days. Of those three days, I complete six topics a day. I’m still in that system. Slipped a bit because I have to put my attention to two other classes and somewhat procrastinated. But now I’ve realized I’ve put so much time in Aleks, I’m somewhat behind in other classes. And I wanted to try and enjoy my weekend whilst maintaining Aleks and I’m seeing a module that is due March 5 of next month that I haven’t touched due to me working on the current module (which I have 33 topics remaining out of 140 I think so I’ve been doing good). 

And I have to work this weekend, but it looks like I may have to call out both days to maintain Aleks and other class work. Which is already bad because I haven’t been working as much recently. 

So now I’m just frustrated and confused on my options because Aleks is taking up too much of my time). And I’m not kidding when I say I have had full on panic attacks due to trying to complete Aleks to pass the class with a C or above. Anyone else?
